subject: Re: Call of Cthulhu: Typo Report: ¶6, ¶7; more name-dot confusion
msgSnippet: ... What about ù for lack of a better term ùáquasi-adjectival nouns? For example, Egyptian in the Egyptian was surprisingly adept on the snowboard; some
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Timothy" <tim_rice09@...> wrote:
>
> As a rule, I avoid dotting adjectives, even if they are the possessive of an unambiguously dotted noun.

What about  for lack of a better term  quasi-adjectival nouns? For example, "Egyptian" in "the Egyptian was surprisingly adept on the snowboard; some of the others in the group wondered if he'd been practicing indoors in a building in Dubai or something."

In "Rodriguez the Portuguese" "Portuguese" is name-dotted, and I'm having trouble thinking up a nice, crisp rule for when to name-dot things and when not to.
